title: 111_s3936
content: The "States as Energy Leaders for the Future Act" or "SELF Act" defines terms like "eligible entity" and "Secretary" for the Clean Energy Grant Program. The Department of Energy established a program to provide grants to develop clean energy and carbon reduction measures, including renewable electricity standards, climate action plans, and incentives for energy efficiency improvements. The Department of Energy established a program to provide grants for clean energy and carbon reduction measures, including standards for energy efficiency, participation in regional greenhouse gas reduction programs, on-bill financing for energy efficiency improvements, State tax incentives for clean energy components, innovative financing mechanisms, best management practices for public utility commissions, grid technology updates, and carbon efficiency standards. Eligible entities include States, local governments, and regional entities. The program offers grants for clean energy and carbon reduction measures, including energy efficiency standards, participation in greenhouse gas reduction programs, on-bill financing, State tax incentives, innovative financing, best management practices for public utility commissions, grid technology updates, and carbon efficiency standards. Eligible entities must meet requirements set by the Secretary and submit an application for consideration. The Secretary determines grant recipients and amounts based on specified criteria. The Secretary will determine grant recipients and amounts based on information provided in applications and criteria developed by regulation. Grant funds must be used for eligible purposes specified by the Secretary. Regulations establishing criteria for grants will be issued soon after the enactment of the Act. Grant funds provided under this section must be used for eligible purposes specified by the Secretary through regulations. The Secretary will issue regulations establishing criteria for grants, including eligible measures, application criteria, and a point system for reviewing applications. Considerations for the regulations include regional energy disparities and clean energy potential. The Secretary will develop regulations for grant applications, considering regional energy disparities and clean energy potential. An explanation of how grants will be objectively evaluated based on the criteria will be published in the Federal Register. Authorization of $5 billion for fiscal year 2011 to carry out the Act, with funds remaining available until expended. Cost offset for clean energy grant program and deficit reduction by denying deduction for major integrated oil companies for income from domestic production of oil, gas, or primary products. The amendment to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 denies deduction for major integrated oil companies for income from domestic production of oil, gas, or primary products, with an effective date for taxable years beginning after December 31, 2010.
